Nice
Nice!
Nice contribution !

Nine men morris is a solved game, isn't it? I'm not opposed to include a solved game in CG, but the following issues have to be considered:

(1) is the game solvable within the CG time and memory constraints? I think the answer is yes.
(2) If the answer to the previous question is yes, is it OK that the top players games will always end in a draw? The ranking will be quite irrelevant.

If the author/moderators don't think these issues are important, then it is a fine contribution. Mind you, this opens the door for multitude of other solved games.
very nice game, i like it
Breaking changes, new input fields during initialization for neighboring fields.

Nice game !
I don't know what others think, but I think it'll be nice if you sent the neighbors of each cell at the beginning of the game (as they did for this spring challenge for example). So that if people want to calculate themself some possible move from a position it'll be easier. For example to do a Monte Carlo Tree Search it'd be helpful
Updated parts of game and text.

Textual error:

Move stone When all stones are placed, the player can move one stone per turn and to one adjusting free field

Probably should be:

Move stone When all stones are placed, the player can move one stone per turn to a neighbouring free field.

EDIT: I see a few more errors like this, though the one above is the most problematic one. Before it gets approved, someone should go through the text and fix them. Let me know if you want me to do this.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tried and appreciate this board game and would like to go on improving my AI on real arena.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice board game. Love the idea that is was already played in very ancient times.
Hello, is there some 3-fold repetition detection for a draw, or game will be in endless cycles until max rounds are used?
How about displaying the name of the places. It would greatly help to visually interpret the text input.

Hello Dartisan,
Would be worth indicating that 0 is white and 1 is black. So the first player to play is 1, not quite usual in cg.

You need to provide the board as in put each round IMO.
List of:
0: empty
1: my piece
2: enemy piece

Thanks for your feedback, I will consider it, when I see more interest in the game. Perhaps also to consider, as the computing time is limited, you lose more time, in reading and initialising on each turn the board than in reading and executing the last move on your tracked board. 
Had the same reflection in proposing the possible moves, it makes the game more friendly to enter, but has a cost for the ones try to calculate the max of possibilities.
Yes, I had seen this too, would investigate it later, for sure linked in the input/output operations, the current order is not on purpose, but would be fixed.

Currently these informations are in the game summary like: 

Game Summary:
Player Default played (PLACE C3)

But I can take a look to place the information also on the graphical Interface. Currently I check more the engine for ensure that it is stable and bugfree. How do you like the base gameplay, say the ruleset for an AI engine?
Hi, there is currently no repetition detection, in case the game is not won until max rounds, it ends in a draw.
Thanks
Thanks
Thanks, I have corrected. When you see other points, your welcomed to correct them, or give me any feedback and I will do as fast as possible. All feedback is appreciated.

Thanks for bringing it back, we were wondering what happened with the game :)
Will test soon!

Thanks for feedback, but there are already the last movement, the list of all stones on fields and the list of all possible movements. These informations keep an easy entry (as Ultimate TicTacToe) and keep all possibilities for custom implementations for the personal AI.

I agree on the point, that the game is solved, as you can see on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solved_game. Some other games on CodinGame you find also on the list. 

 Still I think the different phases and winning condition by taking stones or blocking movements and the time limit 50ms could keep it challenging.

I also agree, draws are in this game more frequent than other board games , this by it's nature. How it will finally affect the ranking, I think still the top Bots will not be based on randomness but by calculation.
wow tummai
Thanks
Yes I know, too fast these days :-) Sorry to let you wait so long.
Thanks
Thanks

I'm convinced. I personally do not care about it being a solved game, but I wanted to raise the issue in case someone with more experience in the game says it is trivial.

I would love to have it on the platform. The more, the merrier :)

It's a solved game, but I strongly doubt you can do it in less than a second. Probably takes an hour at least.

The guys that solved it used generated endgame books with a size of like 5-10 GB. Try to fit that in your bot :)

Best thing you can do is just try to solve it locally, see how long it takes. I will do it over the summer if noone else has. First have to finish my oware experiment.

BTW: the only other game on that list that is solved and on CG is checkers and that is *really* hard to do. Our connect 4 (9x7) is not solved.

I think the size of the statespace is similar to Onitama, Bandas and Oware. Each of these can't be solved on CG for the following reasons:

Onitama: some starts are solvable in 1 second, but they were excluded for this reason. The other starts are probably all solvable within an hour, but there's 100k+ different ones.

Bandas: Same as onitama, only even more starts, but each of them also probably solvable in an hour if you have some endgame books

Oware: I was able to get endgame books to 36 seeds in 3 weeks. I think it's solvable with some cloudcomputing and maybe $5k or so. Again, not in a reasonable time for CG. Also this assumes no turn limit. With a turn limit of 200 things get complicated.

I'm not 100% sure where nine men's morris fits in this list, but as I said, try it :)

In Ultimate tic-tac-toe there is no "movement" so it's easy to know which move are possible I think. Here If I wanted to do a MCTS I'd have to hard code the table of neighbors with G7 → G4,D7 etc. which is annoying imo

Allright. The easiest way to use the rest of my feedback is to paste the text below into https://text-compare.com/  or https://www.diffchecker.com/ together with the current description to see the changes (they will light up)

I made around 20 changes to the text. Most are error fixes, some are improvements to the sentence structure. Hope it helps! Don't feel obligated to use it all. A few things are just preference.

=========================================================





Image Source Wikipedia The board on the right is meant to show the system of coördinates. The lines do not not correspond to the game nine men's morris

The game has a Debug Mode, showing the field positions.

The game is played in 3 phases:


1.	Place stone Each player has 9 stones. The stones are placed one per turn on a free field.
2.	Move stone When all stones are placed, the player can move one stone per turn to a neighbouring free field.
3.	Flying When a player has only 3 stones left, he can move one of his stones to any free field.
Capture When by placement or movement a player form a mill, meaning three of his stones in a vertical or horizontal line, he must take an opponent stone. Stones that are in a mill can only be taken if no other stones are available to capture.

Winning
The player who takes all but 2 stones from the opponent or hinders the opponent from making a move on the next turn, wins.

Draw
When after 200 movements no player has won, the game is declared to be a draw.
 Rules
Mill
A mill is an alignment of three stones in vertical or horizontal by placing or moving a stone on a previous empty field of the line. When creating a mill, the player takes a stone from the opponent. First only stones not forming a mill are allowed to be taken. When all stones are bound in a mill, the player can take any stone of the opponent.

Place stone
PLACE ; field1
PLACE: The command to place a stone
field1: The field on the board to place the stone. It must be free. As Example A1

PLACE&TAKE ; field1 ; field2
PLACE&TAKE: The command to place a stone. This command has to be used when placing forms a mill.
field1: The field on the board to place the stone. It must be free. As Example A1
field2: The field on the board with the opponents stone to take. As Example A2

Move stone
MOVE ; field1 ; field2
MOVE: The command to move a stone
field1: The field on the board containing the stone the player want to move. As Example A1
field2: The field on the board to move the stone to. It must be a free and neighbouring field. As Example D1
Thanks for the work, I have reworked the text and have retaken most of your recommendations.

I was talking about displaying the name of every places in the graphical display, like for example in the second Wikipedia graphic. To easily locate  a place by its name.

Or at least display the  column letters and row numbers on the border of the play board.

I see, you mean the coordinates of the fields. I will look if there is a nice way, but I think it would be more a border description as a field description, as it will be covered by stones. But perhaps I try to make it on a debug way, not yet experimented with it, but could be a nice experience.
I have a provisory Debug Mode now implemented, perhaps when I get more votes I will come back, and clean the design.
Perfect.
Fixed it, the documentation I will improve later.
There is no input for the last move done by the enemy?

Sorry, I see, had missed to put it in the loop. Will provide it soon. You're right this information is mandatory. The other outputs like board and possible moves are nice to have, and a point to eval execution time / use.
Now also a variable for the board is available.
